meta.content: A hybrid control strategy for the three-phase dual-active-bridge (3P-DAB) converter of LVDC applications is presented to improve the power conversion efficiency under light load conditions. The 3P-DAB converter is an attractive topology for high-power applications such as railway traction and aircraft due to its inherent the zero voltage switching (ZVS) capability and reduction of conduction loss due to an interleaved structure with seamless bi-directional power transitions. However, conventional phase shift modulation (PSM) applied to a 3P-DAB converter has disadvantages such as ZVS failure under light load conditions. In this paper, an asymmetrical pulse width modulation is inserted into PSM to replace the existing modulation algorithm of a 3P-DAB converter with a simple control approach. In the proposed control, the transferred power can be calculated according to the mode changes. In addition, the soft switching area of the power switches can be expanded by the proposed hybrid control strategy. Finally, experimental results validate the proposed hybrid modulation strategy using a 3-kW prototype 3P-DAB converter.

div.p: A hybrid control strategy for the three-phase dual-active-bridge (3P-DAB) converter of LVDC applications is presented to improve the power conversion efficiency under light load conditions. The 3P-DAB converter is an attractive topology for high-power applications such as railway traction and aircraft due to its inherent the zero voltage switching (ZVS) capability and reduction of conduction loss due to an interleaved structure with seamless bi-directional power transitions. However, conventional phase shift modulation (PSM) applied to a 3P-DAB converter has disadvantages such as ZVS failure under light load conditions. In this paper, an asymmetrical pulse width modulation is inserted into PSM to replace the existing modulation algorithm of a 3P-DAB converter with a simple control approach. In the proposed control, the transferred power can be calculated according to the mode changes. In addition, the soft switching area of the power switches can be expanded by the proposed hybrid control strategy. Finally, experimental results validate the proposed hybrid modulation strategy using a 3-kW prototype 3P-DAB converter.

LVDC distribution systems are continuously being researched and investigated to construct DC microgrids (MGs), which can be a substitute for existing AC grid systems. DC grids can provide high quality electric power to DC household applications. In addition, a DC MGs can use electricity more effectively than a conventional AC grid system with reduced transmission losses [
1
,
2
,
3
]. Figure
1
shows the conceptual structure of a DC grid system. As shown in Fig.
1
a, to implement a DC MG, an LVDC distribution system is necessary. The LVDC system requires that high voltage (kV) should be converted to the level of the application voltage such as 380 V, i.e., a converter interfaced with the LVDC system should cover a high power and a high voltage [
4
,
5
]. In addition, bi-directional power conversion is required, since a DC MG can be good for consumers to act as an electricity seller.

Example of a DC grid
a
Common DC distribution system,
b
target LVDC system structure [
6
]

Figure
1
b shows the target LVDC system structure with input/output voltages and output power. One of the suitable candidates for the power conversion system of the LVDC system in Fig.
1
b is a single-phase dual-active-bridge (SP-DAB) converter, since it has great benefits like inherent the zero voltage switching (ZVS) capability without any additional resonant components and smooth bi-directional transitions [
6
,
7
,
8
,
9
,
10
]. However, the SP-DAB converter is not effective in terms of power density in high power applications. In the case of the SP-DAB converter, high capacitive filters are required for high power or high current operations, which makes the issue of volume a practical matter [
6
,
7
,
8
,
9
,
10
,
11
].

A three-phase dual-active-bridge (3P-DAB) converter can be an alternative solution instead of a SP-DAB converter. As an extension of the SP-DAB, the 3P-DAB converter shown in Fig.
2
has the same advantages as the SP-DAB converter. In addition, the 3P-DAB converter has additional advantages when compared to the SP-DAB converter. Due to its interleaved structure, the 3P-DAB converter can reduce the conduction losses of high-power/high-current applications. In addition, the 3P-DAB converter can obtain a higher effective operating frequency than the SP-DAB converter, which can improve power density. Typically, the effective operating frequency of the 3P-DAB converter is three times higher than the switching frequency [
11
,
12
,
13
]. However, like the SP-DAB converter, this topology has the disadvantages of practical limitations such as ZVS failure under the light load conditions [
12
,
13
,
14
]. For the ZVS condition, the minimum negative current is necessary. However, the current under light load conditions is not sufficient to obtain ZVS, which results in hard commutations of the power switches. This is due to the fact that the parasitic output capacitors of power switches exist in practice. Several modulation strategies have been studied to overcome the disadvantages of the 3P-DAB converter. Triangle modulation and trapezoidal modulation are introduced for 3P-DAB converters by connecting two of the three bridges in parallel [
12
,
13
,
14
]. Although these methods can improve power conversion efficiency under several load conditions, the 3P-DAB converter only operates as an SP-DAB converter with an interleaved structure, which has limitations in terms of performance and size [
15
]. In [
16
,
17
,
18
], a simultaneous duty-cycle control with the phase-shift modulation (PSM) and asymmetrical duty-cycle control have been proposed. Even if overall efficiency can be improved, these control algorithms are too complex to implement in a practical manner, since the degree of freedoms (DoFs) are simultaneously controlled to regulate the output voltage and to deliver the power.
Circuit diagram of a three-phase dual-active-bridge converter

In this paper, based on the existing PSM for 3P-DAB converters, PWM control is inserted to improve the power conversion efficiency under the light load conditions with a simple control algorithm. Using an analysis of the ZVS mechanism of a 3P-DAB converter, the hybrid control modulation is designed to expand the ZVS area. A comparison between the proposed hybrid modulation strategy and PSM under light load conditions is presented in this paper. Finally, the validity and performance of the hybrid modulation strategy are demonstrated using simulation and experimental results of the 3 kW 3P-DAB prototype.

A hybrid modulation algorithm for the 3P-DAB converter is presented to expand the ZVS region under light load conditions with a simple control. Problem statements of the 3P-DAB converter under the existing PSM are given. To overcome the limitation of the 3P-DAB converter, a hybrid APWM-PSM, which is divided into five operating modes, is proposed. An accurate analysis of resonance is presented and used in the design of the ZVS condition of the hybrid APWM-PSM. Theoretical waveforms are presented and an output power analysis for each of the modes is derived based on a mathematical approach. To validate the effectiveness of the proposed hybrid APWM-PSM algorithm, simulation and experimental results obtained with a 3-kW prototype converter were obtained. Finally, the F-ZVS region is expanded by shifting its borderline by almost 5% from 490 to 300 W when the APWM-PSM is employed.
